newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP's Hopp says insider probe harmful.
newsitem.headline: SAP's Hopp says insider probe harmful.

text.p: Massive public interest in a probe into possible insider share trading at German software house SAP AG has caused great harm to the company, chief executive Dietmar Hopp said on Wednesday.
"The unbelievable uproar over this process is likely to have caused major financial damage," Hopp said in remarks he was due to give to the company's annual shareholders meeting.

But Hopp repeated earlier assertions that he saw no reason to doubt the dependability and discretion of workers with access to sensitive figures who had signed written pledges to abide by Germany's 1994 insider trading law.

Frankfurt prosecutors have launched an investigation into trades by over 100 people in both SAP shares and financial derivatives after sharp price movements around October 23 last year. SAP stock plunged by a quarter in value after the release of weaker than expected third quarter profits, prompting an investigation by the Frankfurt bourse's supervisory watchdog.
Hopp, in the text of a speech he was due to give to shareholders, said he had supported the insider investigation and wanted the affair to be cleared up as soon as possible.
